title: Redesign 2
text:
Bad Graph 2
Tourist Generating Countries to United States of America

This graph is a U-shaped ribbon design that represents the top 20 tourist-generating countries that visit the United States.

Key Elements: Country Flags and Names Each country is representative of their flag, name, and Tourist Number.
Ribbon design: The ribbon does the work of visually linking the countries; however, it does not have any specific predefined structure to the design.
Order: By the number of tourists, though hard to decipher from this visualization



Why is this graph not effective?

Confusing Design: Ribbon hard to follow for tourist numbers. Perhaps a bar chart could be more intuitive.
Cluttered: Twisting path and tightly fit labels in graph make graph hard to read.
Inconsistent Scaling: Because the size of countries has nothing to do with the amount of tourists, large discrepancies - such as between Canada and Mexico - are not resolved.
No Visual Metric: The number of tourists is shown only as text; there is no visual metric (like a bar).
Non-Linear Layout: There’s no hierarchy in the ribbon - hence comparisons are challenging.
Over-Use of Colors: Colors add no information, resulting in a graph that is more complicated than it needs to be.



Revised Chart - 1








Why is this a good chart?

Clear design: it is very easy to compare tourist figures by means of the horizontal bars. Long bars mean more tourists and provide faster feedback visually
Color-coding by Continent: Each color represents the different continents that those countries belong to, such as yellow for Europe and red for Asia. That allows a viewer to see at a glance where the most tourists come from.
Good Use of Available Space: Bars are placed in order with no unnecessary crowding or overlapping.
Balance in Visualization: The largest values (Mexico and Canada) leap off the screen without overpowering the smaller values.
Easy Legend: The color coding is described in the legend, and by it, one may easily relate every country to its respective continent.



Graph Insights
From this “Number of Tourists by Country” bar chart, we can identify that:

Top Contributors: The United States receives the most tourists from Canada and Mexico, represented by the longest bars.
Continental Breakdown: North America is in the lead, colored in green, followed by Europe, colored in yellow, then Asia in red.
Smaller Contributors: Countries like New Zealand and Switzerland send less tourists, as depicted by shorter bars.
Easy comparison: Such a chart makes it easy to compare the number of tourists from one country with those from another.
Global representation: The graph represents the tourists coming to the United States from the rest of the world.

This map very clearly shows which countries send the most and fewest numbers of tourists to the United States, arranged by continents.


Revised Chart - 2








Why is this a good chart?

Global Overview: It clearly shows which nations send the most tourists.
Color Gradient: The blue-to-yellow scale clearly indicates which countries have more tourists, like the United States, Canada, and Australia.
Easy-to-understand Legend: Itself shows how much the number of tourists for each color is. 
Efficient Usage of Space: It shows all countries on this map without it being confusing or cluttered. 
Simplicity in Design: Its minimalist design helps draw the attention of a viewer to presented data.



Graph Insights
The “Number of Tourists by Country” heat map may indicate the following:

Top Contributors: Canada, Mexico, and Australia will lead the numbers of tourists coming to the United States. These will be shown in yellow.
Regional Trends: The highest numbers of tourists are found to come from the regions of North America, Europe, and Oceania.
Lower Contributors: Somber colors will be used for countries in Africa and parts of Asia, which yield lower numbers.
Easy Comparison: The gradient in color will ensure ease of comparison of each country’s contribution of tourists in a swift manner.
Global View: The map represents the fact that tourists are coming from all the corners of the world, though with huge differences in quantity.

This map aptly identifies which countries send the most and least tourists to the United States of America in a world-wide context.

title: Data Visualisations
text:
Data visualization is the presentation of data in a graphical manner to effectively and succinctly convey information. It includes visualizations such as charts, graphs, and maps to facilitate the comprehension of patterns, trends, and insights by users through data. Data visualization simplifies interpretation, analysis, and the presentation of information through the conversion of complex data into visual forms.


A terrible graph is one that actually misleads or confuses the viewer, and this is usually the result of some bad decisions about the design or inappropriate data representation.
Some of the major characteristics of a poor graph include, but are not limited to:

Cluttered design: too much information in one picture is confusing.
Inconsistent scaling: No values are shown on the graph elements such as bars and bubbles.
Lack of clarity: Poor labeling, ambiguous legends or inadequate use of color are some reasons for the same.
Misleading visuals: Distorted axes or 3-D effects misrepresent the actual meaning of the data.
Unnecessary complexity: An overtly complicated graph is difficult to deduce anything useful from.




A good graph is one which depicts the data in a simple and accurate manner. The readers may comprehend it without much fuss. Good graphs possess the following traits:

Clarity: An uncluttered design with labels, titles, and legends that enable the user to grasp the facts in an instant.
Accuracy: The use of proper scaling while maintaining the same kind of graphic presentation to show data.
Good space management means appropriate layout without overcrowding and too much white space.
The right type of visualization: Type of chart or graph that best fits the data.





Improve understanding: Visualization puts complex data into digestible form, as it enables the analysis of data.
It draws out patterns and trends which, if left in their raw state, might go totally unnoticed.
Clear visualization at all instances helps businesses and people arrive at data-driven decisions.
Engages the audience: An effective image draws attention; there is a better way of communicating a message than text alone.

In summary, data visualization plays an important role in simplifying data analysis and making insights easy to understand and show; this makes all the difference between an excellent graph and a terrible one.

title: Redesign 1
text:
Bad Graph 1
Dept Ratio: Total Liabilities/Total Assets

This map compares states’ debt ratios-total liabilities divided by total assets-along with the dollar amount of those liabilities.

Size of the bubble: This indicates the size of the total liability such that the larger the bubble, the larger the liability.
Color Gradient: Green represents low debt ratios, red represents high debt ratios, and neutral colors represent middle levels.
Red represents the states with a high debt ratio: For example, Illinois and New Jersey are very high, while Texas and Florida are rather low.



Why is this a bad graph :

Double Encoding Confusion: Size and color are two different measurements, and it’s hard to focus on both.
Overlapping Bubbles: States-especially for densely populated areas like the Northeast-overlap and are hard to read.
No Clear Scale: Color gradient does not have numeric scale helping to explain debt ratio numbers.
Map distortion: Extremely large states like Texas and California dominate this map, based not on their economic condition but based on their size alone.
Misleading visuals: States that have high liabilities but low relative debt ratios - Texas is a good example of this, might appear worse than smaller states that have much higher debt ratios.
Geographical Irrelevance: For all practical purposes, this map says little, and the same comparison is better made via a bar chart or a dot plot.



Revised Chart - 1
Total Liabilities by State: Bar Chart








Why is this a good chart?

Clear Visualization: The bar chart allows comparison in which states have more liabilities compared to the rest.
Direct Comparison: X-axis has states listed on it and y-axis has liabilities, so comparison is done very quick visually
Logical Scaling: y-axis is labeled in billions, so you get an idea of an exact value.
Clean design: It doesn’t have anything superfluous, and in this graph, viewers can directly focus on the data.
Read easily: Since it is a linear arrangement, one can easily spot states with high liabilities, like California and Texas.



Graph Insights
Based on the “Total Liabilities by State” bar chart, we can conclude:

Large disparities: Some states have far larger liabilities than others.
Top three states: California (CA), Illinois (IL), and New York (NY) have the biggest liabilities, as indicated by the tall bars.
Low-Liability States: Wyoming (WY), Vermont (VT), and South Dakota (SD) have very low liabilities, shown by their short bars.
Easy Comparison: The chart clearly illustrates which states have the highest and lowest obligations.
Concentration: The majority of liabilities are concentrated in a few states, with the others having modest or low levels.

This graph allows you to simply compare state liabilities and discover those with the most financial responsibilities.


Revised Chart- 2
Total Liabilities by U.S. State Geospatial Map








Why is this a good chart?

Geographical Context: You can compare state liabilities with one other while still seeing geographical context.
Color Gradient: Darker blue represents more liabilities, lighter blue, less. You get an idea from a glance which states owe more than others.
Clear Legend: The chart conveys liability ranges, which prohibits one from misjudging the data.
Clean Design: It’s just a map without irrelevant details, making it look cluttered; it is all about data.
In an Instant: You get quick insights through color-coding-for instance, knowing which states are high-reliability by the darker blue without reading the numbers.



Graph Insights
Based on this “Total Liabilities by U.S. State” map we may draw the following conclusions:

Regional Differences: Each state is in a different shade because each state displays a different level of liabilities, in a range of blues.
High-Liability States: The states of Michigan (MI) and California (CA) display the highest liabilities shown in dark blue.
Low-Liability States: Lighter blue states - often in the Midwest and West - have lower liabilities.
Easy to Compare: Due to a color gradient, liabilities of different states are easily compared to one another.

This map clearly depicts those states with financial liabilities that are either the highest or the lowest.

title: Codes
text:
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(plotly)


library(plotly)
library(readxl)
debts <- read_excel(“debts.xlsx”)
bar_plot <- plot_ly( data = debts, x = ~State, y = ~Total Liabilities (Billion $), type = ‘bar’, name = ‘Total Liabilities’, marker = list(color = ‘darkolivegreen’) # Example with named color ) %>% layout(title = ‘Total Liabilities by Debt’, xaxis = list(title = ‘State’), yaxis = list(title = ‘Total Liabilities (Billion $)’))
bar_plot



library(plotly)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
debts <- read_excel(“debts.xlsx”)
custom_colorscale <- list( c(0, ‘lightyellow’),
c(0.25, ‘khaki’),
c(0.5, ‘gold’),
c(0.75, ‘darkgoldenrod’), c(1, ‘darkred’))
choropleth_map <- plot_ly( data = debts, locations = ~State, locationmode = ‘USA-states’, z = ~Total Liabilities (Billion $), type = ‘choropleth’, colorscale = custom_colorscale, colorbar = list(title = “Total Liabilities (Billion $)”) ) %>% layout( title = ‘Total Liabilities by U.S. State’, geo = list( scope = ‘usa’, projection = list(type = ‘albers usa’), showlakes = TRUE, lakecolor = toRGB(‘white’) ) )
choropleth_map

title: Codes
text:
Visualization 2:
library(readxl)
library(ggplot2)
library(plotly)
library(dplyr)

Redesign 1:
library(plotly)
library(readxl)
data1 <- read_excel(“data1.xlsx”)
p1 <- ggplot(data1, aes(x = reorder(Country, -Number_of_Tourists), y = Number_of_Tourists, fill = Continent)) + geom_bar(stat = “identity”) + coord_flip() + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + labs(title = “Number of Tourists by Country”, x = “Country”, y = “Number of Tourists”) + scale_fill_manual(values = c( “Asia” = “chocolate4”, “Europe” = “cadetblue”, “North America” = “darkmagenta”, “South America” = “darkseagreen4”, “Africa” = “aquamarine4”, “Oceania” = “brown” )) theme_minimal()
interactive_plot <- ggplotly(p1)
interactive_plot


Redesign 2:
library(rnaturalearth)
library(dplyr)
library(plotly)
library(readxl)
data1 <- read_excel(“data1.xlsx”)
world <- ne_countries(scale = “medium”, returnclass = “sf”)
merged_data <- world %>% left_join(data1, by = c(“name” = “Country”))
p <- ggplot(merged_data) + geom_sf(aes(fill = Number_of_Tourists, text = paste(“Country:”, name, “Tourists:”, scales::comma(Number_of_Tourists)))) + scale_fill_gradientn( colors = c(“lightblue”, “yellow”, “red”, “chocolate4”), # Define a custom color gradient labels = scales::comma ) +
labs(title = “Number of Tourists by Country”, fill = “Tourists”) + theme_minimal()
interactive_map <- ggplotly(p, tooltip = “text”)
interactive_map
